title: Carminite
text:
Carminite (PbFe3+2(AsO4)2(OH)2) is an <a href="anhydrous">anhydrous</a> <a href="arsenate%20mineral">arsenate mineral</a> containing <a href="Hydroxyl%20radical">hydroxyl</a>. It is a rare <a href="Supergene%20%28geology%29%23Oxidized%20zone">secondary mineral</a> that is structurally related to <a href="palermoite">palermoite</a> (Li2SrAl4(PO4)4(OH)4). <a href="Sewardite">Sewardite</a> (CaFe3+2(AsO4)2(OH)2) is an analogue of carminite, with <a href="calcium">calcium</a> in sewardite in place of the <a href="lead">lead</a> in carminite. <a href="Mawbyite">Mawbyite</a> is a <a href="dimorph">dimorph</a> (same formula, different structure) of carminite; mawbyite is <a href="monoclinic">monoclinic</a> and carminite is <a href="orthorhombic">orthorhombic</a>. It has a <a href="molar%20mass">molar mass</a> of 639.87 g. It was discovered in 1850 and named for the characteristic carmine colour.
Structure.
Carminite belongs to the <a href="orthorhombic">orthorhombic</a> crystal class (2/m 2/m 2/m) and has <a href="space%20group">space group</a> C ccm or C cc2. The structure consists of linked <a href="octahedra">octahedra</a> of <a href="iron">iron</a> surrounded by <a href="oxygen">oxygen</a> and <a href="hydroxyl">hydroxyl</a> which are aligned parallel to the <a href="Crystal%20structure">c axis</a>. They are connected together in the direction of the an axis by <a href="arsenate">arsenate</a> <a href="tetrahedra">tetrahedra</a> (<a href="arsenic">arsenic</a> surrounded by 4 <a href="oxygen">oxygen</a>). <a href="Coordination%20number">Coordination</a> about the <a href="lead">lead</a> <a href="atoms">atoms</a> is eight-fold. The edges of the <a href="unit%20cell">unit cell</a> have lengths a = 16.59 <a href="Angstrom">Å</a>, b = 7.58 Å and c = 12.295 Å. There are 8 formula units in each unit cell (Z = 8).
Appearance.
Crystals have been found up to 2 cm long, though most are smaller. They are typically <a href="Crystal%20habit">bladed</a>, elongated along the <a href="Crystal%20structure">c axis</a> and flattened perpendicular to the <a href="Crystal%20structure">b axis</a>. They also occur as <a href="Acicular%20%28crystal%20habit%29">acicular</a> crystals, in <a href="spherical">spherical</a> or tufted <a href="Crystal%20habit">aggregates</a> and as <a href="Crystal%20habit">fibrous</a> or <a href="Crystal%20habit">drusy</a> masses. The crystals are a characteristic carmine red colour, hence the name, and they are also red in <a href="Ray%20%28optics%29%23Special%20rays">transmitted</a> light. They are <a href="translucent">translucent</a> with a vitreous <a href="Lustre%20%28mineralogy%29">lustre</a> and a reddish yellow <a href="Streak%20%28mineralogy%29">streak</a>.
Physical properties.
Carminite is fairly soft, with a <a href="Mohs%20hardness">Mohs hardness</a> of , between that of <a href="calcite">calcite</a> and <a href="fluorite">fluorite</a>. Because of the <a href="lead">lead</a> content it is heavy, with <a href="specific%20gravity">specific gravity</a> of 5.03 - 5.18, although specimens from <a href="Mapim%C3%AD%20Municipality">Mapimi</a> are less dense at 4.10. <a href="Cleavage%20%28crystal%29">Cleavage</a> is distinct in one direction parallel to the <a href="Crystal%20structure">c axis</a>. The mineral is slowly soluble in <a href="hydrochloric%20acid">hydrochloric acid</a> (HCl) with the separation of <a href="lead%28II%29%20chloride">lead(II) chloride</a> (PbCl2) and totally soluble in <a href="nitric%20acid">nitric acid</a> (HNO3). Carminite is not <a href="radioactive">radioactive</a> and no <a href="piezoelectric%20effect">piezoelectric effect</a> has been detected.
Optical properties.
Orthorhombic crystals (and monoclinic and <a href="triclinic">triclinic</a> crystals) have two directions in which light travels with zero <a href="birefringence">birefringence</a>; these directions are called the <a href="Optic%20axis%20of%20a%20crystal">optic axes</a>, and the crystal is said to be biaxial. The speed of a <a href="Ray%20%28optics%29">ray</a> of light travelling through the crystal differs with direction. The direction of the fastest ray is called the X direction and the direction of the slowest ray is called the Z direction. X and Z are <a href="perpendicular">perpendicular</a> to each other and a third direction Y is defined as perpendicular to both X and Z; light travelling along Y has an intermediate speed. <a href="Refractive%20index">Refractive index</a> is <a href="Proportionality%20%28mathematics%29%23Inverse%20proportionality">inversely proportional</a> to speed, so the refractive indices for the X, Y and Z directions increase from X to Z.
Carminite is <a href="orthorhombic">orthorhombic</a> and for an orthorhombic crystal the optical directions correspond to the <a href="Crystal%20structure">crystal axes</a> a, b and c, but not necessarily in that order. For carminite the orientation is X = c, Y = a and Z = b and the <a href="refractive%20indices">refractive indices</a> are high, with nα = 2.070, nβ = 2.070, nγ = 2.080, only a little less than <a href="diamond">diamond</a> at 2.4.
The maximum birefringence δ is the difference between the highest and lowest refractive index; for carminite δ = 0.010.
The angle between the two <a href="Optic%20axis%20of%20a%20crystal">optic axes</a> is called the optic angle, 2V, and it is always <a href="angle%23Types%20of%20angles">acute</a>, and <a href="Bisection">bisected</a> either by X or by Z. If Z is the bisector then the crystal is said to be positive, and if X is the bisector it is said to be negative. Carminite is biaxial (+) and 2V is moderate to large. 2V depends on the <a href="refractive%20indices">refractive indices</a>, but refractive index varies with <a href="Color%23Physics%20of%20color">wavelength</a>, and hence with colour. So 2V also depends on the colour, and is different for red and for violet light. This effect is called dispersion of the optic axes, or just dispersion (not to be confused with chromatic dispersion). If 2V is greater for red light than for violet light the dispersion is designated r > v, and vice versa. For carminite the dispersion is strong, with r < v.
The mineral exhibits strong <a href="pleochroism">pleochroism</a>; when viewed along the X direction it appears pale yellowish red and dark carmine red along the Y and Z directions. <a href="Absorption%20%28electromagnetic%20radiation%29">Absorption</a> is equal along the Y and Z optic directions, but less along the X optic direction.
When a birefringent crystal is rotated between crossed <a href="polarizers">polarizers</a> it will turn dark every 90° of rotation. This effect is known as <a href="Extinction%20%28optical%20mineralogy%29">extinction</a>. Carminite exhibits the parallel extinction that is characteristic of orthorhombic crystals.
Occurrence.
Carminite is formed as an uncommon <a href="Supergene%20%28geology%29%23Mineral%20alterations">alteration product</a> of <a href="arsenopyrite">arsenopyrite</a> (FeAsS) in the <a href="Supergene%20%28geology%29%23Oxidized%20zone">oxidized zones</a> of some lead-bearing deposits. Common associates are <a href="wulfenite">wulfenite</a>, <a href="scorodite">scorodite</a>, <a href="plumbojarosite">plumbojarosite</a>, <a href="mimetite">mimetite</a>, <a href="dussertite">dussertite</a>, <a href="cerussite">cerussite</a>, <a href="beudantite">beudantite</a>, <a href="bayldonite">bayldonite</a>, <a href="arseniosiderite">arseniosiderite</a> and <a href="anglesite">anglesite</a>.
The <a href="Type%20locality%20%28geology%29">type locality</a> is the Louise Mine, <a href="B%C3%BCrdenbach">Bürdenbach</a>, Altenkirchen, Wied Iron Spar District, Westerwald, <a href="Rhineland-Palatinate">Rhineland-Palatinate</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a> where it is associated with <a href="beudantite">beudantite</a>. At the <a href="Hingston%20Down">Hingston Down</a> Consols mine in <a href="Cornwall">Cornwall</a>, <a href="England">England</a>, carminite occurs with <a href="scorodite">scorodite</a>, <a href="mimetite">mimetite</a> and <a href="pharmacosiderite">pharmacosiderite</a>.
The ores of the <a href="Ojuela%20Mine">Ojuela Mine</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, are <a href="Polymetallic%20replacement%20deposit">replacement deposits</a> in <a href="limestone">limestone</a> and consist of <a href="galena">galena</a>, <a href="sphalerite">sphalerite</a>, <a href="pyrite">pyrite</a>, and <a href="arsenopyrite">arsenopyrite</a> in a <a href="matrix%20%28geology%29">matrix</a> of <a href="quartz">quartz</a>, <a href="Dolomite%20%28mineral%29">dolomite</a> and <a href="fluorite">fluorite</a>. Arsenopyrite is abundant. On a dump near the north shaft blocks of massive <a href="scorodite">scorodite</a> containing seams and pockets of <a href="arseniosiderite">arseniosiderite</a> and small areas of <a href="dussertite">dussertite</a> and carminite have been found. Carminite also occurs as masses mixed with <a href="cerussite">cerussite</a>, <a href="anglesite">anglesite</a> and <a href="plumbojarosite">plumbojarosite</a>. It is almost always intimately associated with <a href="arseniosiderite">arseniosiderite</a> and <a href="dussertite">dussertite</a>.
